title: 114_hr3295
content: The Department of Justice is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance in fiscal year 2015. This includes funding for various programs such as the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. $10,000,000 is allocated for Juvenile Justice Programs for community-based violence prevention initiatives, including public health approaches to reducing shootings and violence. Additionally, funding is provided for Community Oriented Policing Services programs. $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States and $15,000,000 for statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for investigative purposes. The funds allocated for investigative purposes will be used to locate and investigate illicit activities, specifically related to the distribution of heroin and unlawful prescription opioids, as well as targeting unlawful traffickers through statewide collaboration. The Small Business Administration receives $4,000,000 for entrepreneurial development programs and $1,000,000 for business loans. The Department of Labor receives $265,000,000 for training and employment services. The Department of Health and Human Services receives funding for maternal and child health through the Health Resources and Services Administration. The curr_chunk discusses additional funding for various initiatives including maternal and child health, substance abuse treatment, choice neighborhoods initiative, and community development fund. The funding amounts allocated are $50,000,000 for Healthy Start Initiative, $10,000,000 for drug court grants, $170,000,000 for Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. These funds are to remain available until September 30, 2016. The curr_chunk discusses an additional $500,000,000 for the Community Development Fund to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be awarded to states, tribes, or local governments based on criteria determined by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The additional $500,000,000 for the Community Development Fund will be used to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Grantees must submit a plan detailing the use of funds, eligibility criteria, and how funds will address long-term recovery and restoration in impacted areas. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will specify approval criteria for these plans within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will approve or disapprove plans within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Funds allocated will not affect non-emergency formula allocations. Grantees must receive training on grant management and include performance requirements in contracts. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in administering the funds. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in administering funds, up to 30% can be used for immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 may be transferred to Program Office Salaries. Up to $10,000,000 may be transferred for necessary costs of administering funds under this heading. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028, with no changes unless mutually agreed upon. Agencies must report financial data for policy evaluation. The Act provides emergency funding designated by Congress, subject to the President's approval. It is named the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
